summary: Fund managers have had more success beating the S&P 500 over the long term than the short term. Here are the top 20 actively-managed large-cap mutual funds over 10 years through June 28, 2011, according to Morningstar.

headline: Top 20 U.S. Large-Cap Mutual Funds in 2011
summary: Beating the S&P 500 hasn't been easy this year. Here are the top 20 actively-managed large-cap mutual funds through June 28, 2011, according to Morningstar.

summary: The Treasury will sell $27 billion in three-month bills and $24 billion in six-month bills.

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for July 1, 2011

headline: Fly Me to the Moon
summary: A robotics professor at Carnegie Mellon hopes to build a spacecraft capable of carrying one of his robots to the moon. Here, the process of building a lunar lander.

headline: DJIA's Fireworks: Best Week in Two Years
summary: U.S. stocks surged, and the Dow industrials notched its biggest weekly gain in two years, as a strong reading of manufacturing activity lifted investor spirits ahead of the long holiday weekend.

headline: The Amazing Strauss-Kahn Case
summary: The roue, the maid and the mysterious $100,000 deposit.

headline: Campaigning Against Power in Thailand
summary: Chuvit Kamolvisit, once one of the biggest players in the sex business, is likely to be voted into the losing side of Parliament.

headline: Minnesota Government Shuts Down
summary: Minnesota encountered its second government shutdown in six years as Democratic Gov. Mark Dayton and GOP lawmakers failed to compromise on closing the state's $5 billion budget gap.

headline: GoDaddy Bought By KKR, Others
summary: GoDaddy Group a closely-held company that registers Internet domain names, agreed to be bought by private-equity firms KKR, Silver Lake and Technology Crossover Ventures.

headline: Honda Warns of Sharp Sales Drop
summary: Honda is headed for a significant drop in U.S. sales in July and August as a result of dwindling stocks of its cars and trucks, the company suggested on Friday.

headline: Jenkins: Law vs. Baseball Law
summary: Dodgers owner Frank McCourt tries a brushback pitch on Bud Selig.

headline: Bayer Settles Rice Suit
summary: Bayer agreed on Friday to a $750 million settlement with U.S. rice farmers who had sued the German drugs and chemicals company after two of its genetically modified traits contaminated their crops.

headline: Obama Nominates Chief for OCC
summary: The choice of Thomas Curry could represent an attempt to find a nominee acceptable to bankers and consumer advocates alike.

headline: Biggs: U.S. Needs Massive Public Works Program
summary: Barton Biggs, managing partner at multibillion dollar hedge fund Traxis Partners, painted a bleak outlook for the developed world with only huge government intervention likely to improve things.

headline: Traders Peel Back Japan Hedges as Stocks Stabilize
summary: Investors are peeling back protective options hedges against Japanese stocks built amid the throes of the March earthquake and tsunami that devastated parts of that country.

headline: Nike and NFL's Vick Team Up
summary: Nike has signed an endorsement deal with Michael Vick, restoring a relationship ended by a dog-fighting scandal that landed the NFL quarterback behind bars.

headline: Google Hires 12 Lobbying Firms Amid FTC Probe
summary: Google has hired a dozen lobbying firms as it looks to defend itself in an antitrust probe from critics who say the Internet company has abused its position as the dominant player in Web searching and online advertising.

headline: Photos of the Day: July 1
summary: In today's photos, a U.S. Marine corporal receives a promotion in Afghanistan, a fire truck drives past the devastation of wildfires in New Mexico, painted protesters take a stand against bull-fighting in Colombia, and more.

headline: Rep. McCotter Unveils Presidential Bid
summary: Michigan Republican Rep. Thaddeus McCotter filed papers to run for president in 2012, joining the race as a long-shot candidate hawkish on foreign policy and sympathetic to labor unions.

headline: Court Rules Fate of Yucca Site Rests With Regulators
summary: An appeals court ruled that a decision on a proposed nuclear-waste dump in Nevada still rests with U.S. regulators, handing a victory, at least for now, to the Obama administration and other opponents of the Yucca Mountain site.

headline: Corporations Boost Buybacks, Insiders Stand Back
summary: U.S. companies are buying back stock at a blistering pace this year, but the executives who run the companies aren't showing the same appetite.

headline: Factory Data Weigh on Crude
summary: Crude-oil prices fell on fresh worries about the health of the global economy after weak manufacturing data from China and the bloc of euro-using nations.

headline: Subprime Mortgage Index Soars
summary: A bellwether index of subprime mortgage bonds surged after the New York Fed suspended auctions from its Maiden Lane II portfolio of mortgage securities acquired in the AIG bailout.

headline: Gold Closes at 6-Week Low
summary: Gold prices slid to six-week lows below $1,500 an ounce,  as optimism about Greece's debt situation and strength in global stock markets sapped demand for the metal as a refuge.

headline: SEC Postpones More Swaps Rules
summary: U.S. securities regulators temporarily suspended more swaps rules set to take effect this month in an effort to prevent market confusion.

headline: Minnesota Government Shuts Down
summary: Gov. Mark Dayton and Republican lawmakers failed to reach a budget agreement, meaning state parks and the Minnesota Zoo will be shut, and thousands of state workers will be furloughed.

headline: Google, Among Others, Considering Bid for Hulu
summary: Google is among the companies that Hulu's advisors have reached out to as they begin to hunt for a bidder.

headline: For Europe's Stocks, a Clean Sheet of Gains
summary: European stocks rose for fifth time this week, led by banks and assisted by stronger-than-expected U.S. data. The Stoxx Europe 600 surged 4.1% for the week, its best weekly showing in a year.

headline: Vodafone's Messy Clean-Up
summary: Investors should give Vodafone more credit for its ongoing portfolio clean-up. If the U.K. telecom group can avoid more trouble in India, its shares could have further to rise.

headline: Execution Drug Sees New Hurdle
summary: Danish drug maker Lundbeck said it is establishing a new distribution system to deny U.S. prisons access to a drug used in executions.

headline: California Online Tax Law Pressures Amazon
summary: Amazon.com may soon have to collect sales taxes in California after an online tax-collection bill was signed by the governor. Amazon said the law won't change anything about its California business. A spokeswoman declined to comment on whether Amazon would challenge the law.

headline: Obama to Nominate Comptroller Head
summary: Obama will nominate Thomas Curry, a member of the FDIC board, to be Comptroller of the Currency in a move designed to fill an open slot at a key banking agency.

headline: Relaxed Luxury, Raw Wilderness
summary: During a two-week honeymoon safari in southern Africa, Journal editor Sara Clemence and her husband experienced the juxtaposition of relaxed luxury and raw wilderness that never failed to surprise or delight.

headline: Christopher & Banks, Quantum Fuel Systems Technologies Worldwide: Biggest Price Gainers (CBK, QTWW)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

headline: Great Moments in Tennis Fashion History
summary: Today's male tennis pros dress in bold colors and are often swathed in corporate logos. It's a world apart from tennis styles at the turn of the 20th century, when men played in button-front shirts and flannel trousers. Here's a look at some key men's tennis styles through the decades.

headline: Reliance Drags India Shares Lower
summary: Indian shares broke a six-session win streak as Reliance Industries, the country's biggest company by market value, slumped, with investors fretting over reports that federal investigators are probing a former upstream regulator for allegedly favoring private-sector energy companies.

headline: Asian Shares Mostly Higher
summary: Asian markets ended mostly higher Friday as concerns over Greece's debt problems took a back seat after its austerity program cleared a final hurdle in parliament. Japan's Nikkei Stock Average climbed 0.5% to 9868.07.

headline: Vodafone to Pay Tax on Essar Stake Buy
summary: Vodafone Group has agreed to pay withholding tax on the purchase of a stake in Indian unit Vodafone Essar from joint venture partner Essar Group, two people familiar with the matter said.

headline: Trimax IT Infrastructure Files Draft IPO Document
summary: Trimax IT Infrastructure & Services said it has filed a draft document with India's capital markets regulator for an initial public offering of 11.98 million shares.

headline: South Africa Considers Nationalization
summary: The nationalization debate in South Africa is gaining "alarming" momentum and that is causing investors to shy away from putting needed capital into the country at a time when the European Union crisis will start to have an impact on developing country economies, the head of the South African Chamber of Commerce and Industry said.

headline: A Boss on the Road
summary: The Ford Mustang Boss 302 prompts Dan Neil to ask: "What do you call a car so evolved it ceases to be a member of the species it evolved from?"

headline: Ex-Taiwan President Lee Comments on Indictment
summary: Former Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui said about his indictment for embezzlement that prosecutors had created the charges "out of thin air."

headline: Immigration Row Engulfs U.K. Minister
summary: U.K. business organizations have fiercely criticized a senior government minister for telling them to employ more British people rather than hiring "labor from abroad."

headline: Monaco Awaits Its Princess
summary: After waiting decades for Prince Albert II to choose his bride, residents of this high-flying Riviera principality are preparing to embrace South Africa's Charlene Wittstock to succeed Grace Kelly as Princess of Monaco.

headline: Tata: Growth Prospects for TCS to Remain Robust
summary: Tata Consultancy Services Chairman Ratan Tata said growth prospects for India's largest software outsourcing company by revenue will remain robust, underscoring his conviction in the sustained demand for software services, despite weakness in the global economic environment.

headline: Japanese Yields Rise
summary: Japanese government bond yields crept higher as investors trimmed holdings of safe-haven assets after a quarterly Japanese survey logged better-than-expected business spending forecasts.

headline: Currency Insurance Could Gain Favor
summary: Foreign money now pouring into fast-growing emerging markets might have trouble getting back out, if the political situation were to get chaotic. The World Bank's MIGA can insure against that.

headline: China Researcher Pushes Higher Duties on Luxuries
summary: Far from cutting taxes on imported luxury goods, China needs to raise duties to help redistribute wealth, a senior researcher with the Ministry of Finance argued, saying these taxes are "aimed at the wealthy and undoubtedly are beneficial to social fairness."

headline: Heavy Monsoon Rains Approach North India
summary: Heavy monsoon rains are expected over northern India in the next three to four days, two officials at the India Meteorological Department said.

headline: Stephen Colbert Gets FEC Permission to Form 'Super' PAC
summary: Comedian Stephen Colbert won approval from the Federal Election Commission to start a political organization that he plans to use to promote or oppose candidates in the 2012 election. The ruling may affect politicians and other political groups.

headline: Full Tilt Owner Finds Buyer
summary: A group of European investors agreed to buy a majority stake in Pocket Kings, an Irish company that owns Full Tilt, a website at the center of a U.S. crackdown of online poker.

headline: Strong Franc Slows Swiss Growth
summary: Switzerland's industrial sector grew at a slower pace in June, as the marked appreciation of the country's currency against the euro and the dollar and a slowdown in worldwide growth started to take their toll.

headline: India's Trade Deficit Widens
summary: India's May trade deficit widened by nearly 50% from a year earlier as manufacturers imported more capital goods even as exports grew at a brisk pace.

headline: BOJ: Post-Quake Sentiment Fell Sharply
summary: The Bank of Japan's quarterly tankan survey showed that Japanese corporate sentiment worsened sharply in the aftermath of the March 11 earthquake, with the closely watched index for large manufacturers turning negative for the first time in over a year.

headline: Mehraj-ul-Alam Celebrations
summary: Thousands of Muslim devotees flocked to Hazratbal shrine in Srinagar, in Jammu and Kashmir, to mark the anniversary of the day on which many believe Prophet Muhammad ascended to heaven.

headline: Iran Warns on Crude Supplies to India
summary: Iran has warned it will stop crude oil supplies to India from August if its long-pending bills aren't cleared and a favorable mechanism for future payments isn't set, executives at two Indian refiners said.

headline: Mizuho Securities Reaches for Lender's Coattails
summary: Mizuho Securities aims to swing to a profit this fiscal year by strengthening ties with Mizuho Corporate Bank as part of a restructuring effort at Mizuho Financial Group.

headline: Emerging Europe: The Week in Photos
summary: See a roundup of photos from central and eastern Europe, including a water dance in Prague and Hillary Clinton's visit to Hungary.

headline: Northumbrian Water Confirms Bid From CKI
summary: Cheung Kong Infrastructure has confirmed its interest in buying Northumbrian Water after the U.K. utility said that it has received a non-binding indicative cash proposal from the Hong Kong property firm.

headline: Lloyds Banking to Cut 15,000 Jobs
summary: Lloyds Banking will cut 15,000 jobs and focus on four key U.K. units as it seeks to cut annual costs by $2.41 billion within three years, its CEO said.

headline: Danes Approve Border Controls
summary: A Danish parliamentary committee has approved the government's contested plan to re-establish permanent customs checkpoints at Denmark's borders.

headline: An Emerging Opportunity in Stocks
summary: Emerging-market equity investors had a tough time in the first half of 2011. But will the second half offer richer pickings?

headline: Coal India Overseas Plans on Hold
summary: Coal India has halted its plans to acquire coal mines abroad because of delays in getting government approval, said the state-run company's interim chairman, Nirmal Chandra Jha.

headline: Potash Nourishing Uralkali
summary: Potash prices have run up sharply this year, but is this fertile ground for investors?

headline: Indian Accent's Summer Menu
summary: New Delhi's Indian Accent recently unveiled its new menu. Here are a few samples, in pictures.

headline: Murray's Time Is Now
summary: It's not a match he hopes he can win: it's a match he thinks he can win. And that can make all the difference as Andy Murray prepares to take on Rafael Nadal in the semi-finals of Wimbledon. Nor is Murray alone in thinking rather than hoping.

headline: India Manufacturing Plunges in June
summary: Manufacturing activity in India in June slowed sharply from a month earlier, plunging to a nine-month low as prolonged monetary tightening crimped economic activity.

headline: Indian Philanthropists Giving More
summary: Donating to charity is a growing trend among high net worth individuals in India, according to a report by Bain. In pictures.

headline: Maruti, Tata Sales Hit by Costlier Loans, Fuel
summary: Maruti Suzuki India and Tata Motors, two of India's largest auto makers, posted declines in vehicle sales for June as high inflation, rising loan rates and price increases continued to hurt demand.

headline: U.K. Public-Sector Strike Has Uneven Impact
summary: Workers from British schools, the border control agency and other state services mounted a one-day strike over plans to raise their retirement age and require them to pay more toward their pensions.

headline: Japan's June Auto Sales Sag, but Rebound on Track
summary: Japan's auto sales slumped 23% from a year earlier in June, marking the second straight month of slower declines and signalling that auto makers are rebounding from a sales plunge after the March 11 earthquake disrupted vehicle supplies to customers.

headline: Abhijeet Power to Launch IPO
summary: India's Abhijeet Power said Friday it has filed a draft share sale document with the capital markets regulator for an initial public offering to raise up to 13.75 billion rupees.

headline: Another Turtle Bay Milestone
summary: North Korea will chair a U.N. arms control agency.

headline: Sun Pharma Bets on Emerging Markets
summary: To help sustain its growth momentum, the Indian generic-drug maker is seeking opportunities beyond its traditional U.S. market, where benefits from patent expirations are expected to wane after 2015.

headline: Macau June Gambling Revenue Up 52%
summary: Gambling revenue in Macau rose 52% in June from a year earlier, government statistics show, as visitors from mainland China continued to fuel strong growth in the only place in China where casino gambling is legal.

headline: India Fuel Retailers' Daily Losses Narrow
summary: The daily revenue losses of India's state-run oil marketing companies on discounted fuel sales have fallen 43% after the federal government raised diesel and cooking fuel prices and cut import and excise taxes, government data showed.

headline: Posco's India Land Buy Unlikely to Resume Before July 12
summary: The land acquisition for Posco's proposed $12 billion steel plant in India's eastern state of Orissa is unlikely to resume before July 12 as the state government will be busy organizing security and facilities for a major religious festival, a person familiar with the matter said.

headline: Samsung Reunites  Component Manufacturing Operations
summary: Samsung ElectronicsCo. said that it will fold its flat-panel display business back into its semiconductor business, uniting its component manufacturing operations just when the display business appears likely to be unprofitable for some time to come.

headline: Polish Billionaire to Buy Polkomtel for $5.43 Billion
summary: Polish businessman Zygmunt Solorz-Zak has agreed to buy Polish mobile operator Polkomtel for 15.1 billion zlotys ($5.43 billion) in cash, four Polkomtel shareholders said in separate statements.

headline: Qantas Struggles to Secure Deal With Fiji
summary: More than a year since a sale was raised with the government of Fiji, Qantas is no closer to securing a deal for the South Pacific nation to pay $40 million to buy out its stake of national carrier Air Pacific.

headline: India in Pictures
summary: A devotee in the Ganges, Karnataka State Police drills, tribal dancers in West Bengal and more. Some snapshots.

headline: World Bank Removes Wipro from List of Barred Entities
summary: The World Bank has removed Indian software exporter Wipro from its list of entities barred from doing business with it, the website on procurements and vendors for the bank showed.

headline: China's Communist Party Turns 90
summary: China's Communist Party marks its 90th anniversary Friday, and residents are pulling out all the stops to celebrate, from hosting revolutionary song-singing competitions to performing patriotic ballets.

headline: Air India Seeks to Spin Off Units
summary: The debt-laden state-owned airline plans to spin off its engineering and ground-handling units pending government clearance as part of its turnaround strategy.

headline: Stocks End June With Four-Day Streak
summary: U.S. stocks surged for a fourth straight day to give a strong close to the second quarter amid encouraging Chicago-area economic data and a pledge from German banks to support heavily indebted Greece.

headline: As Kluge's Empire Fell, Trump Bought
summary: As Patricia Kluge's empire collapsed, Donald Trump bought. Over the past six months, he swooped in and picked up many of the pieces of her palatial Virginia estate and winery.

headline: What's News
summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Asia.

headline: New Stadiums Foul Out With Merchants
summary: Two years after new stadiums were opened for the Yankees and the Mets, local businesses around the ball parks are still looking to future prospects to improve their financial scorecards.

headline: U.S. Set to Probe CIA Jail Deaths
summary: Attorney General Holder ordered a criminal probe into the deaths of two prisoners interrogated by the CIA in the years following the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorism attacks.

headline: Motorola Sees China Success
summary: Motorola Mobility Holdings' CEO said smartphone sales in China are growing rapidly, despite the fact that the usual Google Android functions aren't available there. He concedes the lack of Google features may be a bigger problem for its Xoom tablets in China.

headline: Greece Boosts Its Gold Holdings
summary: Greece's central bank increased its gold reserves marginally in May, choosing not to sell some of its vast holdings as efforts continued to trim the public debt.

headline: Trump Battles Bank of America
summary: Bank of America repossessed a mansion owned by billionaire divorcee Patricia Kluge and is trying to sell it. But Donald Trump owns the front yard and much of the surrounding property, and has a right of first refusal.

headline: Judge Rules That Bulger Can Use Public Defender
summary: James "Whitey" Bulger, the alleged crime boss found with more than $800,000 in his Southern California apartment when he was arrested last week after 16 years on the lam, will be represented by a public defender over the government's objections.

headline: Cairn, Vedanta Get India's OK
summary: India conditionally approved Cairn Energy's proposal to sell a big stake in its Indian unit to miner Vedanta.

headline: Thailand's Military Is Wild Card in National Elections
summary: With Yingluck Shinawatra leading opinion polls, analysts said the key question is whether Thailand's conservative armed forces will accept an election outcome Sunday that places the youngest sister of exiled populist billionaire Thaksin Shinawatra in Thailand's top job.

headline: A Mozart Fable, Stripped Down
summary: Peter Brook's production of "A Magic Flute" takes a minimalist approach.

headline: Fed Halts Mortgage-Bond Auctions
summary: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York suspended plans to auction off a large portfolio of mortgage bonds following weeks of turmoil in the credit markets, even as it rebuffed a fresh overture from American International Group Inc. to buy all the battered bonds.

headline: Pension Rulings Could Aid Cutbacks
summary: In rulings that may bolster efforts to roll back public pensions nationwide, judges in Minnesota and Colorado have thrown out lawsuits challenging recent cuts to retiree benefits.

headline: Cozy and Eclectic in Hong Kong
summary: For those looking for a cozy and slightly more upscale lunch venue in Hong Kong's Wan Chai district that's not, say, The Pawn, there's a new contender on the block (the same block, actually): Madam Sixty Ate.

headline: Dodgers Had to Pay Fee for Financing
summary: The Los Angeles Dodgers had to pay a previously undisclosed fee of nearly $5 million to secure the financing package that will allow the team to continue operating through bankruptcy.

headline: Nasdaq Weighs Approach to LSE
summary: Nasdaq OMX Group is assessing a possible approach to the London Stock Exchange Group, potentially reviving an effort that the U.S. exchange had abandoned in 2007.

headline: Remark Leads to Analyst's Suspension
summary: Cable news network MSNBC suspended political analyst Mark Halperin hours after he disparaged President Obama on the network's "Morning Joe" show.

headline: Kevin Spacey Is the Perfect 'Richard III'
summary: In the final year of the Bridge Project, Sam Mendes's "Richard III" finds the perfect vehicle to cast a convincing Kevin Spacey, star of "The Usual Suspects" and "Seven."

headline: EU-South Korea's Lucrative Trade Deal
summary: A trade agreement between South Korea and the European Union will enter into force Friday, creating an estimated $30 billion in new trade annually, and potentially taking away market share from U.S. companies by eliminating tariffs.

headline: Fourth of July Music Festivals
summary: Plus, "Project Nim," "As You Like It" from Royal Shakespeare Company in New York.

headline: Obama Pushes for Deficit Deal by July 22
summary: The Obama administration believes congressional leaders must agree to a deficit-reduction deal by July 22 in order to raise the government's borrowing limit in time to avoid a default in early August.

headline: Homes With Private Docks
summary: Anchors aweigh—homes with private docks in Key Largo, Fla., Chenequa, Wis., and Armonk, N.Y.

headline: N.J. Constitution Aids Effort to Cut Pensions, Benefits
summary: Gov. Chris Christie declared that New Jersey was a "model for America" this week when he signed a law cutting pensions and health care for current and retired public workers.

headline: The Danish Lesson
summary: Copenhagen finds a bank that is not too big to fail.

headline: Chávez Says He Has Cancer
summary: Venezuelan President Hugo Chávez went on television Thursday to tell the world what many suspected for days but that his government had denied: He has cancer.

headline: Something Completely Different
summary: The British invade with "Torchwood: Miracle Day" for Starz; and newly naturalized Americans explain why they are staying here on HBO's "Citizen U.S.A."

headline: H-P Girds for Battle
summary: Friday will be a key test for Hewlett-Packard as it aims to launch its first tablet computer to rival Apple's iPad.

headline: A Modern Country Homestead
summary: A scientist couple grow their own food at their remodeled Sonoma retreat.

headline: China to Ease Procurement Rules
summary: China's Finance Ministry is scrapping certain rules that foreign companies say favored domestic products for government procurement, a big step toward easing concerns among global companies.

headline: Twist in Strauss-Kahn Case
summary: The sexual-assault case against former International Monetary Fund leader Dominique Strauss-Kahn appeared to be weakening as prosecutors and his defense team prepared to raise questions about the credibility of the maid who accused him.

headline: The Crossover King
summary: German-born George II protected the British crown from a serious Jacobite challenge and was the last sovereign to personally lead British troops in battle. Martin Rubin reviews Andrew Thompson's history of an oft-overlooked monarch.

headline: Kabul Bank Probe Yields First Arrests
summary: Afghan officials said Thursday they have detained the former chairman and chief executive of Kabul Bank, the first arrests since widespread graft was exposed at the lender nearly a year ago.

headline: Buy Bonds or Bye, Bonds?
summary: Investors returned to their bond-buying ways in the second quarter. Now, with the Federal Reserve's so-called QE2 bond-buying program in the past, some wonder whether the bond market can carry its second-quarter momentum forward.

headline: Our Boroughs, Ourselves
summary: If ever there was proof that we in New York are a bunch of spoiled brats, it is evident when it comes to inter-borough dating.

headline: Bubble Talk Surfaces in Web IPOs
summary: LinkedIn. Pandora. Groupon. Facebook. Internet IPOs—planned, executed or otherwise—are hot again. Now, the question floating from Silicon Valley to Wall Street is whether we're in a bubble again.

headline: President Gets Flak for Jet-Tax Idea
summary: The reaction to Obama's targeting of a tax break for corporate-jet ownership shows how discussion of even small, largely symbolic tax increases can provoke angst in the affected industry—and how tough it will be to reach a debt deal.

headline: Project Retains Its Edgy Design
summary: A luxury residential developer plans to build a new condo near Madison Square Park using an edgy design left over from a stalled hotel project.

headline: Lloyds Bets Big on U.K. Recovery
summary: Antonio Horta-Osorio has set out a strategy based around cost cuts and tying the bank's fortunes more closely to that of the U.K. economy. That's a rational decision.

headline: Medicare to Cover Drug for Prostate Cancer
summary: The federal Medicare agency said it approved nationwide coverage of the Dendreon medicine Provenge in certain prostate-cancer cases.

headline: 'Dynasty' on DVD
summary: "Dynasty," "Mannix" and "Eureka" will all be released on DVD next week.

headline: Wimbledon's Loud Year
summary: In the final weekend, Murray's fans, Kvitova's "yelps" and Sharapova's fiancé should produce a noisy finish.

headline: Smile, You're on Camera
summary: What is that makes food and television go so well together —or, more to the point, achieve such high ratings? Bruce Palling explores.

headline: Manhattan Apartment Sales Hit Jogging Speed
summary: The Manhattan residential market has entered a period of stability, brokers and analysts said, with steady sales, flat prices and inventory, even while many other housing markets are in an uncertain struggle.

headline: Asia Economy Slows
summary: Asia's economy continued to gear down in June, with manufacturing activity in China slowing for a third straight month as price pressures eased, suggesting that Beijing's efforts to reduce inflation are bearing fruit.

headline: Covering a Multitude of Beach Sins
summary: There's a time and a place for the wearing of a caftan, and the heady days of summer provide the perfect showcase for something big and floaty—with the added advantage of covering a multitude of sins and offering sun protection too.

headline: U.S. Reaches Out to Islamist Parties
summary: The Obama administration is reaching out to Islamist parties whose political power is on the rise in the wake of Arab Spring uprisings across the Middle East and North Africa.

headline: Opening Bidder Picked for Borders
summary: Borders Group chose Direct Brands, a company owned by private-equity firm Najafi, as the opening bidder in a looming bankruptcy-court auction of the big bookseller.

headline: What's on Around Europe
summary: The Weekend Journal's guide to exhibitions, concerts and events across Europe.

headline: Israeli Facebook Campaign Keeps Lid on Cheese Prices
summary: Israel's powerful dairy companies have surrendered to a three-week boycott and Facebook campaign and pledged to lower prices on cottage cheese, as Israeli consumers take on rising prices.

headline: Euro Gains After Greece Vote
summary: The euro topped $1.45 after Greece's parliament voted to implement austerity measures. The common currency hit a two-week high against the Swiss franc as investors unwound their short-euro positions.

headline: China Police Detain 36 in Alibaba Probe
summary: Police in eastern China have detained 36 people in an investigation of fraudulent listings on online trade platform Alibaba.com that came to light in February.

headline: Ringing in the Revolution
summary: This week's jazz calendar leads off with a tribute to Django Reinhardt, as well as some Fourth of July festivities.

headline: This Train Is to Die For
summary: On the online review site Yelp, amateur critics will tell you that the thinly pounded tuna with foie gras at Le Bernardin is to die for. They rave about Locanda Verde's sheep's milk ricotta. And then they weigh in on the Q train.

headline: Turkey's Economy Expands 11%
summary: Turkey's economy accelerated faster than expected in the first quarter, underlining the emerging economy's growth momentum but feeding fears that the economy is overheating.

headline: 'Perfect Round Trip' in Foreign Exchange
summary: Currency markets gave investors a case of whiplash in the second quarter, as expectations swung from optimism about the global economic recovery to worries about a renewed slowdown and yet another flare-up of the European debt crisis.

headline: Neo Rauch Is Inspired by Nature
summary: When Neo Rauch isn't in the middle of a painting, at openings or traveling, the German contemporary artist enjoys nothing more than a quiet weekend at home with his wife and their dog Smylla.
